bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 9, 1940

div1.p: Hench attempts to finish the Rheumatism Review, allowing little time for yellow fever research.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 9, 1940
div1.opener:
y. f.
December 9, 1940
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I feel so appreciative whenever you write to me, and yet I feel apologetic,
knowing that you have to do it by long hand. Some of these days I am going to write you
a long letter, and unfortunately, will be asking you quite a number of questions. It has
pained me that I have had to drop the yellow fever investigations temporarily. I got
into an unhappy jam, trying to finish the Rheumatism Review, as one of my supposed collab-
orators fell down on the job at the last moment very miserably, but another two weeks
will see the Review finished and sent to press.

I was asked to give my talk on yellow fever before our Clinical Society,
which I did last Thursday, and the audience, though small, was most appreciative. I
amplified my Washington and Jefferson talk with sixty slides, and although this lengthened
it considerably, it seemed to add to it greatly.

You asked about the Lazear family. I planned to find out more about them.
As a matter of fact, when I was a boy in Pittsburgh, one of my fairly good friends was
John Lazear. At that time, I know nothing about Dr. Lazear and having left Pittsburgh,
I lost sight of him. He lives a block from my mother's home, and has married into a
very wealthy family, the Harkness family. I haven't see John for years, but mother tells
me he often asks about me, and if I cannot raise funds elsewhere, I am planning to call
on “dear old Johnny” to come across!

I am glad that Dr. Finlay sent you his book, and I am particularly happy
to have your reaction to it. I have read over some of old Dr. Finlay's original papers
and they are fascinating. He certainly had a wonderful intuition, and I quite agree
that American physicians should have given him more credit than he got. I agree with
you that it is unfortunate that Finlay began to make a few extra little claims after it
was discovered that his theories were correct. I suspect that it was these claims that
incited Carroll to his caustic criticism. This just set the argument going, so that
everybody concerned got themselves out on a limb.

If I can, I plan to take a little more extensive vacation this Spring,
going to California to visit Mrs. Lazear briefly, and also General Truby, then relaxing
on a boat through the Panama Canal to Havana, spending a little while there settling up
the matter of a deed to the old building and trying to find out from Dr. Ramos, Secretary
of Defense, how our plans for its memorialization might fit in with theirs. I am sure
that we can make some arrangements satisfactory to all.

I shall be most happy to have the excerpts from your diary, but hate to
have you go to the trouble of coping them by hand. Nevertheless, I realize that you
have trepedition in submitting it to the mail. May I say that I learned as much back-
ground information from your diary as I did specific information. Your diary told me
much of the mechanics of the medical setup, etc.

Several physicians and others have given me suggestions as to where
to publish my remarks, and it looks now as if I would be able to make several
choices. There will be no trouble whatever in getting it published. I think
it would perhaps be best to publish it in two or three papers, but my first job
is to get it in a paper to submit to Dr. Ramos.

May I extent to you and Mrs. Kean our most sincere best wishes
for a happy Christmas season.
div1.closer: Always sincerely and most appreciatively yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
